p.s: In the given excerpt Michel Barnier uses a lot of stylistical devices, wichwhich makes it worth to take a closer look on them by analysing the excerpt.
The main argument is that the EU has the most open market in the world (l. 20), so UK will be able to take part in it after the Brexit, wichwhich will create great costs (l. 3).
His line of arguments starts with the great effect of the Brexiton UK's and EU's economy (l. 9f).
He goes on with a sidenote, a recommendation for buisnessesbusinesses to prepare for the worst case.
After this, he explains that the EU is open for third countries in the financial sector, also for the UK (l. 17) if they accept the regulations of the EU (l. 21f.).
To prove his point, he repeatedly gives the example of the USA, with wichwhich it works (l. 27).
He finishes his speech with the promise of not changing the EU because of the Brexit.
He also calls the EU the most open market in the world (l. 28).

With this line of argumentats, Barnier wants to show the listeners the way to a bright future for UK and EU and that prove that this future is possible to achieve, after the Brexit creating new difficulties and costs.
His choice of words refers to the place where the speech is held.

Him beeingbeing in the European American Chamber of Commerce leads him to often use the USA and its companies as an example (e.g. l. 24) and to using many terms out of trading like agricultural... sector (l. 8), subsidiaries (l. 11) or substituted compliance (l. 23).
Barnier uses the enumeration manufacturing and logistics, as well as the agricultural and food sectors (l. 8) to show that the Brexit will have a great effect on many sectors.
The little contrast of sectors with engines and food or nature, wichwhich are split with the as well as underlines that there are very many sectors affected and also them not having a connection.
With the a little informal saying lose-lose situation (l. 9f.) Barnier points out that nothing good comes from the Brexit and that it will only damage all parties in a very clear and fast way.

The speaker also shows how many things companies need to change and adapt because of the Brexit, implying the great costs and work for every company operating there with the enumeration: to adapt their logistical channels, supply chains and existing contracts (l. 12f.).

The enumeration G20 calls deference, what you call US substituted compliance and what we call in the EU equivalence (l. 22f.) shows that the regulation on supervision of third countries in trading is normed and done in many countries.
The example out of the USA also creates a connection to the listeners out of the USA where the speech was held.
Barnier uses the two rethoricalrhetorical questions (ll. 25f.) to emphasize that the UK can still take part in the financial sector of the EU with the help of the equivalence system.
The example of the USA creates a connection with listeners from the USA again, wichwhich is important because Barnier held a speech about the Brexitin the USA, where this topic is not very important.
All in all, Barnier points out the bad effects of the Brexit on EU and UK, but also shows the way for trading and the financial sector in cooperation in the future.
